awd_titl_txt: SusChEM: Collaborative Research: Efficient biological activation and conversion of short-chain hydrocarbons
awd_abstract_narration:
Advances in the recovery of oil and gas reserves, through the use of fracking and horizontal well drilling, for example, have dramatically increased the amount of natural gas that can be economically harvested in the US. These reserves also contain compounds, know as natural gas liquids (NGLs), that are expensive to convert to useful products using current refinery technology. Fortunately, many microorganisms are capable of consuming NGLs for biomass and energy production using pathways that are much more efficient and less expensive. The biological mechanisms of these conversions will be studied in order to design organisms that exhibit even greater yield of product. By eliminating the generation of waste products and enhancing the effectiveness of these microbes, the resulting technology will be more widely deployed at fracking sites, increasing the energy security of the US while decreasing the negative environmental impact of natural gas extraction. This project will also provide STEM research opportunities to traditionally underrepresented groups, including to high school students through outreach to high schools in Houston, through the Science Academy of South Texas, and through the McNair program at Penn State.

By cloning and repurposing poorly understood alkane-metabolizing enzymes, this project aims to develop metabolically engineered microorganisms capable of converting short-chain alkanes to target products such as butanol. Harnessing alkylsuccinate synthases for such biocatalytic applications requires functionally expressing their partner "activase" enzymes, that require iron-sulfur cluster incorporation, in a microbial host amenable to metabolic engineering. Screens for functional expression of known or putative enzyme pairs and for activation by non-cognate activases will be executed. Enzyme directed evolution strategies to achieve alkylsuccinate synthase activation will also be employed. Functional, heterologous partners will be thoroughly characterized, providing new insights into activase-alkylsuccinate synthase interaction, and new opportunities for biotechnological applications of these and related enzymes. The overall research plan combines protein and metabolic engineering to establish a novel engineering platform for biocatalytic processes with enhanced carbon and energy efficiencies. If successful, this project could transform the commercial processing of NGL away from large, capital- and energy-intensive refinery processing to smaller-scale processes with high mass and energy efficiency. This would in turn eliminate a major source of waste involved in natural gas processing.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
In anaerobic environments, microbial activation of alkanes for subsequent metabolism occurs most commonly through the addition of fumarate to a sub-terminal carbon, producing an alkylsuccinate (AS). AS synthases are complex, multi-subunit enzymes, primarily found in nitrate- and sulfate-reducing bacteria; few have been characterized and none have been reported to be functionally expressed in a heterologous host organism. This project aimed to achieve functional expression of one or more AS synthases in Escherichia coli, so that alkane-derived carbon can be converted to building-block metabolites and ultimately higher-value compounds.

 

Intellectual Merit: A variety of known or putative AS systems were cloned and tested, the host strain was engineered, and culture conditions we optimized, ultimately resulting in functional expression of the (1-methylalkyl)succinate synthase (Mas) system from Azoarcus sp. strain HxN1 in recombinant E. coli. Maximum production of (1-methylpentyl)succinate was observed when masC, masD, masE, masB, and masG were all present, while removing masC reduced production by 66%. We thus established a metabolic engineering platform for oxygen-independent activation and bioconversion of alkanes in E. coli. We subsequently combined protein structure homology modeling with sequence analysis to rationally design variants of this enzyme system conferring improved biosynthesis of select (1-methylalkyl)succinates.

 

Broader Impacts: Research activities supported by this award have included the training of three graduate students. The skills they developed (and subsequently applied) make them valuable assets to the U.S. biotechnology industry; a direct result of this award. This award additionally provided six undergraduate students (several from underrepresented groups in STEM) with the opportunity to receive invaluable, hands-on laboratory training in aspects of molecular biology, and to work alongside/assist graduate students in various capacities (e.g. as volunteers, research fellowship recipients, or through Federal work-study positions).


Last Modified: 10/24/2021
Modified by: Patrick C Cirino

Image
  • A methyl-alkylsuccinate synthase system was functionally expressed in E. coli, enabling anaerobic activation of alkanes, via fumarate addition. Four genes were essential to this activity. These results establish a metabolic engineering platform for oxygen-independent bioconversion of alkanes.
    Yixi Wang, Nam Nguyen
    Copyrighted
    Patrick C Cirino
    Mas expression in E. coli for anaerobic alkane activation via fumarate addition
